title: Question 98

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated for productive cough, pleuritic chest pain, and night sweats of 2 months' duration. He has had two courses of antibiotics for pneumonia without improvement. He lives in Arizona. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable.
On physical examination, temperature is 37.2 °C (99 °F), blood pressure is 119/76 mm Hg, pulse rate is 94/min, and respiration rate is 22/min. Crackles are heard at the anterior right lower chest.
Chest radiograph shows a right middle lobe infiltrate with associated hilar lymphadenopathy.
HIV antigen/antibody combination immunoassay is negative. Sputum Gram stain and acid-fast bacilli stain are negative. Blood cultures are negative. Sputum culture is pending as is

species cause up to 25% of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) cases. In healthy persons, the initial infection is generally contained. However, immunocompromised persons are at risk for dissemination. The differential diagnosis for pulmonary coccidioidomycosis includes bacterial pneumonia, tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, and sarcoidosis. Diagnosis is straightforward in endemic areas and is usually based on clinical manifestations and confirmatory testing by a mycologic culture of affected tissue, histopathologic evaluation of tissue, serology for

antibodies, or urinary antigen testing. Fluconazole is first-line treatment for symptomatic infection. In patients with meningitis, fluconazole is continued for life. In patients who do not respond to azoles, intrathecal amphotericin B may be an alternative.
